awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Puberty and Sociocultural Experiences among Mexican-American Boys
awd_abstract_narration:
Puberty is a time of physical, social, and cognitive changes with direct implications for adolescents' development and long-term well-being. Although scientific knowledge of puberty is growing, there remains little information about how puberty impacts the social and cultural experiences of Latino boys in the U.S. The goal of this project is to understand how biological  and physical markers of puberty relate to everyday experiences of boys from Mexican-American families.  This is a large and rapidly growing group in the U.S. who are at increased risk for high school drop-out, substance use, and delinquency. The study will include interviews with 400 Mexican-American families who have a male adolescent between the ages of 12-16 years old. The project will investigate how boys' pubertal development influences social interactions with their parents, teachers, and friends, and examine how these biological and social factors together impact their mental health and well-being. The research will provide critical information to families, community members, and health care providers about the ways in which puberty shapes the context and development of Latino boys.

Adolescents and their parents will complete in-person interviews that assess puberty, daily stressors, parent-child relationship factors, and key developmental outcomes: mental health, risky behaviors, academic functioning, and ethnic identity. Adolescents will also provide saliva samples to capture biological markers of development measured by levels of puberty hormones. Adolescents will be followed up one year later to assess long-term changes in these same outcomes. The goals of the project are to study the connection between pubertal development and Mexican-American boys' experiences in school and community contexts; test the association between puberty and parent-child relationship factors; and examine how the link between puberty and youths' mental health, risky behaviors, academic achievement, and ethnic identity is explained by both positive and negative social experiences.  The Latino population of the U.S. is growing, and ethnic-racial disparities in social and economic well-being continue.  Understanding biological, social, and cultural determinants of Mexican-American boys' development will contribute to basic knowledge that informs approaches to addressing this critical societal challenge.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Adolescence is a time of physical, social, and cognitive changes with direct implications for long-term well-being. Although scientific knowledge of puberty is growing, there remains little information about how pubertal development impacts the social and cultural experiences of Latino adolescents in the U.S. The original aim of the study was to understand how biological and physical markers of puberty relate to everyday experiences in Mexican-American boys. However, this study launched during the COVID-19 pandemic; thus, with guidance from our community advisory board and NSF program officer, the aims and target population were expanded to include broader developmental experiences, stressors, and well-being of Latino youth (all genders) and their families during the pandemic. Latino adolescents were recruited if they were between the ages of 12-16 years old, had a caregiver who was also willing to participate, and lived in the Southwestern metropolitan area. In-person assessments were not possible during the start of the study due to shelter-in-place orders; thus online surveys were used to assess self-reported measures among families. 

Sociocultural Model of Puberty and Well-Being

The study developed and tested a new conceptual model of sociocultural experiences, puberty, and well-being for Latino youth. We examined how pubertal timing related to developmental factors such as social interactions and parenting behaviors, and how these relate to youths’ depressive symptoms, anxiety, and risky behaviors. Among Latina girls, earlier pubertal timing was associated with less parental warmth. Maternal warmth was related to lower depressive and anxiety symptoms and reduced risky behaviors. For Latino boys, earlier pubertal timing was associated with greater autonomy from fathers, but pubertal timing did not relate to mental health outcomes one year later. 

Developmental and Contextual Considerations during COVID-19

We examined how COVID-19 economic hardship related to Latino family dynamics and youth well-being. Results indicated that parents who experienced more economic hardship during the COVID-19 pandemic also reported greater depressive symptoms, which, in turn, were associated with lower parental warmth. Parental warmth predicted lower adolescent depressive symptoms. Overall, findings showed that economic hardship was linked to more parental depression and in turn lower well-being for youth, but strong family bonds helped reduce the negative impact of parents' depression on their parenting.

Broader Impacts

The project delineates a sociocultural model of puberty and well-being among Latino adolescents and the role of COVID-19 pandemic in shaping youths’ well-being. The findings from this study can inform the ways educators, practitioners, and community members support adolescents and their families. The project created opportunities for engagement within the research community, by involving undergraduate and graduate students, many of whom were from underrepresented backgrounds in developmental science. Additionally, community partners and advisory board members contributed in meaningful ways to the research project.
